posts.name: Breakaway3937
posts.cooked: I remember the day when the majority of teams coded in Labview.
Everyone and their mama uses Java now. We still use C++ I wonder whyâ€¦

posts.name: Pat Mattin
posts.cooked: Java is taught in AP Comp Sci, so teams standardize on it. No compelling reason I can think of to switch to C++ or Python.
Itâ€™s also a feedback loop - more teams use Java so more tooling is developed for Java so more teams use Java and so on.

posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked:
The one compelling reason is performance. We had some pretty complex controls stuff on our bot last year and were still able to swap back to a RIO 1.0 in a pinch without loosing functionality

p.s. donâ€™t switch for performance, use whatâ€™s best for your team

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: Java unfortunately, as itâ€™s the most popular for FRC libraries. Itâ€™s also easy for students to pick up. Also, language â€œspeedâ€ has little to no effect on performance at comps.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
pmattin5459:

No compelling reason I can think of to switch to C++ or Python

Using ROS would be a good reason. While there are ROS java libraries itâ€™s not the same as writing nodes natively. This doesnâ€™t mean your main robot code canâ€™t still be Java and communicate across the gap, but everything else running on the Co-Processor will be c++ or python anyways so why not use one of those on your main bot as well at that point.

ROS is not used by many teams, so I agree not super compelling for most teams.

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked: 9153 is going Python this year because the lead programmer wanted to. Actually he wanted to last year, but I recommended holding off to make sure there were no major issues with the new (officially) supported language. Though weâ€™ll see if that sticks after he graduates or not. I work primarily in Python and love it, but I know many new programmers really benefit from the strong typing.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: Yes definitely study it in the off-season.

posts.name: Brad Collins
posts.cooked:
We transitioned a few years ago from LabVIEW to C++.

I would like, however, to urge my programming team to move to Java next year. Iâ€™m a strong static type guy ( yay Scala, Haskell, and Elm! ), but when thereâ€™s a type mismatch in C++, the error messages are so recondite! Getting types to agree in Java has been much less of a headache. And having spent a number of years programming Java and C# (and Ruby and JavaScript), I chafe at having to manage my own memory and having to split code between a .h and .cpp file.

If I had my druthers, Kotlin would be FRC â€™s first-class language as I love Kotlinâ€™s syntax & feature improvements over Java while having the ability to use existing Java libraries with ease.

And though Iâ€™ve never really fallen in love with Python , I would not be opposed to using it so long as its performance ceiling is not too low. ( Another commenter said that perf is not usually a problem, and thatâ€™s been my experience so far, too. ) Python is so easy to pick up and to teach. Furthermore, it arguably has the largest ROI as students who learn it can use it to do just about anything: one-off scripts, web, ML, Raspberry Pisâ€”the list just seems to go on and on.

posts.cooked: We use Java for the main robot and Python for any coprocessors since Python tends to have much better and easier-to-handle libraries.
